entry.title: Vegas Offsite
entry.content:
So we made this somewhat joke-like promise happen. Our team had an offsite at Vegas this week to celebrate an unbelievable H1.

I took very few photos this trip. Here’s some light adjustment practice. The indoor light is terrible at Venetian on this otherwise nice golden globe. I’m a little surprised to see it reach Popular on 500px within 40 minutes.

On day one I shot guns with friends, had a buffet at Bellagio, and watched the awesome Blue Man Group show.

At Battlefield Vegas, I shot MP5K, UZI, COLT M4, and AK-47. AK-47 is such a beast in automatic mode. In CS the first 3 shots are accurate. In real life, only the first one is! Pretty much all holes outside of 9 are from AK-47 in automatic.

I thought day two might be boring but it actually wasn’t. I watched the last 10 minutes of the Arsenal game during brunch (bad start of the day), engjoyed the hilarious Mac King comedy magic show at an awesome seat, and watched Germany lose at a penalty shootout for the first time.

Lesson learned: never fly with United Airlines. They found a leaking engine after everyone was onboard. The delay was 3+ hours. The other time I flew with United, the delay was 5 hours due to mechanical issues.

entry.title: Hello Atom
entry.content:
Android Studio/IntelliJ have been freezing every few minutes on me, so I decided to move away from it and code Android in Vim just like how I did in my last job. A few things didn’t go well so I tried Atom. It’s not the perfect solution but after a few days of tweaking I’m happy coding in Atom.

I feel the cover picture fits here really well :)

Why not Vim

  1. NERDTree is great, but you can’t change the font just for that plugin. The monospace font takes a lot of space and it’s not be efficient enough for large projects.
  2. Ctrlp sometimes can’t find the file.
  3. Ag always surprises me where it will be after I open a file in a vertical pane. Sometimes NERDTree can be in the middle of two panes.
  4. Syntastic works fine on dynamic languages. I use checkstyle as the java linter, but hope for something better.

Why Atom

I picked Atom over Vim mostly because of its Modern UI. It solves the inefficient space problem in Vim due to the universal font. The Vim mode is not bad, although I can’t just throw my vimrc to it like IntelliJ.

Plugins

Here’s a list of plugins I’m using.

  1. vim-mode is not bad. I noticed the waiting time for a shortcut of two keys is longer than expected. E.g., I can’t use jk to escape because of the long delay. Also there’s no ZZ.
  2. ex-mode so you can do commands after :, such as :w.
  3. terminal-plus works great. After the powerline font and theme colors are set up, it just works and looks like my zsh. I removed one line of code to hide the status bar icon because I mostly just need one terminal and it doesn’t have to take up an entire row above the status bar. The red x button on the right is also annoying.
  4. git-plus is pretty good. No git blame feature though.
  5. blame is the best git blame plugin I can find. It’s not as powerful as vim-fugitive which can look at the entire history. But at least this plugin allows you to copy the hash.
  6. linter and linter-javac. Now I actually just want checkstyle instead. Javac is slow. I had to restrict it to a single file to hide false alarms on some Android and 3rd party imports.
  7. nuclide-move-pane to move tabs to another pane. Atom’s default behavior is weird.
  8. dash is awesome. I had to add Android to the config manually though.

Theme and Syntax

I like the One Dark theme and syntax. Forked the syntax and here’s my own spring-dark-syntax. The colors are from my Vim theme.

Fill in the gaps

Apparently I still miss the accurate jump-to-definition and find-usages from IntelliJ, but Atom looks really cool and has better Vim integration on tab and pane navigation.

I wrote a few scripts to fill some of the domain specific gaps. E.g., take a screenshot on android and pull it; Gradle build the Android project, send a notification when it’s done and push the apk to the device, etc. In that way I open the terminal panel, type one or two keys to trigger the command, close it and continue coding until notified.

entry.title: DualShock 3 on PC
entry.content:
I occasionally game on Windows on my MacBook, and I’ve been thinking about using DualShock 3 since I got one from the PS TV bundle. Previously I was using MotioninJoy and Better DS3 but it only worked when connected via USB. MotioninJoy does not support Apple’s bluetooth module. Found a better approach this weekend.

SCP DS3 is an open source driver that allows DualShock 2, 3 and 4 to work natively on Windows. I followed this post and it worked with USB easily. Then I used Zadig to override the driver so that any bluetooth module can work on SCP DS3.

SCP DS3 is much better than MotioninJoy/Better DS3. It runs as a service so you don’t need to run any app. It connects and works just like on PlayStation, and it’s easy to disconnect by long pressing L1 + R1 + PS. You can customize key bindings but the default one works fine as an Xbox 360 controller. It supports 4 controllers at the same time, and most importantly it’s open sourced. Never worry about MotioninJoy being a trojan anymore.

entry.title: Champion
entry.content:
Slept for 5 hours, flew back from Seattle in the morning, worked for a full day, and drank red bull for the first time - that’s what I did before our indoor soccer playoffs. Crazy.

The playoffs is basically semi-final and final back to back. The semi-final is tough. We were once 1-4 behind and finally won 10-8. Then there’s the final. We had a 5-minute break, whereas the other team had an hour. The scores were really close all the time and finally we won by 8-6! I scored at the final too :)

This is the 3rd season I played. I played most games in the 1st season but not the playoffs due to a project. We lost at the final. The 2nd season was very unlucky that we didn’t have enough girls (3 guys + 2 girls) so we forfeited the semi-final. Finally we won the championship this time. Super proud of the team!

entry.title: Persona 4 Golden
entry.content:
“Persona 4 Golden”, my answer to “What games do you play?” for the past 14 months. Not anymore!

Originally I bought this game and PS Vita so that I could play on a plane. Why P4G? Because when you google it, you see a 9.3/10 from IGN and 9.6/10 from the community. I watched both the P4 and P4G anime before the game and I loved the story so much that I didn’t mind going through it one more time.

The progress was really slow because I only played it on the plane. I tried playing it at home but it felt weird when I connected PSV to the soundbase via bluetooth, but looking down at the 5’’ screen instead of the TV in front of me. So then I bought a PS TV and P4G rendered really nice on it. That really helped speeding it up.

Likes

  • Awesome story
  • Surprisingly good English voices

Dislikes

  • Not self-explanatory skill names in English (but it’s so much cheaper than the Chinese version)
  • Boring quests like catching bugs and fishing with them as baits and feeding the cat 19 fishes

This was the best title on PSV when it was launched, probably still is.
